Title: AI Doom Predictions Are Overhyped | Why Programmers Aren’t Going Anywhere - Uncle Bob's take
Description:
#AI #Programming #TechCareers #ArtificialIntelligence #ChatGPT #AIHype #SoftwareDevelopment #GraceHopper #AITools #TechMyths #unclebob 

Are AI doomsayers right that programmers will soon be obsolete? Or is this just clickbait fear-mongering? In this video, we break down:
Why early programmers panicked when Grace Hopper introduced compilers
How AI tools like ChatGPT compare to human intelligence
The repeating cycles of hype and disappointment in AI history
Why software development is far from fully automatable
The risks of pivoting careers based on AI “doom predictions”
AI is a tool, not a replacement—for now. Understand the trends, separate hype from reality, and make informed career decisions.


Sources:
https://youtu.be/HD0L3lQ9cms?si=4skwzUgqKYMHC9Op

Title: LLMs Are Bottlenecked by Linear Interfaces
Description: Current limitation as I see it So I have been experimenting quite a bit with LLMs recently (see my other posts, especially /state-of-ai-assisted-workflows-october-2025/) and dedicated some serious amount of effort to play around with the tech to both learn more but also to build an intuition for what it is and what it can do well etc. This has led me to having a realisation or an idea, that I’m sure is not unique but I have not seen much about it being mentioned yet.

Title: How I turned Zig into my favorite language to write network programs in
Description: I’ve been watching the Zig language for a while now, given that it was created for writing audio software (low-level, no allocations, real time). I never paid too much attention though, it seemed a little weird to me and I didn’t see the real need. Then I saw a post from Andrew Kelley (creator of the language) on Hacker News, about how he reimplemented my Chromaprint algorithm in Zig, and that got me really interested.

Title: Ossa: Towards the Next Generation Web
Description:
The internet is one of the most impactful technologies of today, enabling billions of people to communicate with family members around the globe, to share photos with one another, and to collaboratively edit documents in real time.
Most of these systems are built on cloud architectures where centralized servers store user information and synchronize that data across user devices.
The image below illustrates how this architecture typically works.
When a user makes an edit on their laptop, the update is sent to a trusted third party server which synchronizes the data and forwards it to another user's cell phone.

Title: Are transformers all we need?
Description:
I vividly remember November 10th, 2017, the day I first read the “Attention is
All You Need” paper. I was in the Paris CDG airport. It struck me how similar
the architecture was to the autoencoders I had learned about just a few months
earlier at the DeepLearn 2017 in Bilbao. The attention mechanism (which I later
learned originated from Dzmitry Bahdanau’s 2014 work) seemed like a remarkably
elegant solution. It captivated me, sparking my deep dive into AI and shaping my
career in applying these models to real-world problems, but I never imagined it
would become the phenomenon it is today.

Title: Language Modeling with Hierarchical Reasoning Models: Lessons from 1M Parameters
Description: The Hierarchical Reasoning Models (HRM) paper made waves by demonstrating strong performance on ARC-AGI reasoning tasks with very few parameters, and the Tiny Recursive Models (TRM) paper pushed it further, setting higher benchmarks with just 7M parameters. The architecture uses hierarchical reasoning through recursion of transformer layers—effectively running the same parameters through multiple forward passes to reach impressive small model performance.

Title: We are all becoming managers – Juan Michelini
Description: AI agents are so good that some days I don’t code anymore: instead, I manage agents. Given a feature, I discuss the requirements with the agent, discuss possible solutions, decide on a design and ask the agent for an implementation.
